title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
Employers spent 4% more on wages and benefits last year as workers received larger pay raises in a tight labor market, rebounding economy and period of accelerating inflation, an increase not seen since 2001.

Rising inflation and the spread of the Omicron variant dented U.S. household spending in December.

---

Major U.S. stock indexes rallied to finish one of their most tumultuous weeks in memory on a high note. The S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow gained 2.4%, 3.1% and 1.7%, respectively.

---

Apple's latest record holiday quarter came in part because of excitement for the iPhone 13 in China.

---

The U.S. Chamber of Commerce is raising concerns about Biden's nominee to become the Federal Reserve's top banking regulator.

---

New York City will require employers to list the minimum and maximum salaries on job postings starting this spring.

---

SoftBank said Chief Operating Officer Marcelo Claure is leaving the company after a dispute over billions of dollars in pay.

---

Chevron had its most profitable year since 2014, reporting net income of $15.6 billion for 2021.
